misconceptions.name: No random number generation or game setup
misconceptions.description: Rubric 0/1: The program does not generate a random number between 1 and 100 or set up a number guessing game. Instead, it implements a road trip cost calculator.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that implementing a road trip cost calculator is an acceptable solution for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program for this question must generate a random integer between 1 and 100 using java.util.Random and store it as the secret number for a guessing game.
symptoms: No import or use of java.util.Random
No variable representing a secret or target number
All variables and logic relate only to cost calculation
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely answered a different problem (road trip cost) instead of the specified number guessing game.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Create a Random object (e.g., Random rand = new Random();) and generate an int answer = rand.nextInt(100) + 1; to use as the secret number for the guessing game.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code has no Random usage or game-like state; it is entirely a different problem.

evidence.note: Main program sets up a road trip cost calculator with no random number generation.

misconceptions.name: No loop to allow multiple guesses
misconceptions.description: Rubric 0/1: The program does not contain any loop for repeated guesses; it performs a one-off cost calculation instead of an interactive guessing game.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe a single-pass calculation without looping is sufficient for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The guessing game must use a loop (while or do-while) so the user can keep guessing until they are correct.
symptoms: No while or do-while loop around user input for guesses
Only three reads for distance, mpg, and price, not repeated guessing
misconceptions.root_cause: Implemented a fixed-input calculation instead of an iterative game.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Wrap the guess input and feedback logic in a while loop that continues until the user's guess equals the randomly generated answer.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code has no loop structure for guesses; only method calls and a single-pass main.

evidence.note: Main performs a sequence of inputs and outputs once, with no loop for repeated guessing.

misconceptions.name: No conditional logic to report guesses that are too high
misconceptions.description: Rubric 0/1: The program does not contain any comparison between a guess and a secret number, so it can never output "Too high".
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems not to be implementing any guessing feedback, only cost computation.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must compare the user's guess to the secret number and print "Too high!" when the guess is greater than the secret.
symptoms: No variables for a guess or secret number to compare
No if-branch that outputs "Too high" or similar message
misconceptions.root_cause: The implemented problem does not involve any guess comparison logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading a guess, use an if statement: if (guess > answer) { System.out.println("Too high!"); } to provide feedback.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no conditional related to a guess; only arithmetic for cost.

evidence.snippet:
double cost = calculateCost(distance, mpg, pricePerGallon);

System.out.println("The cost of driving is $" + cost);
evidence.note: Output only reports cost; no conditional branches for guess comparisons.

misconceptions.name: No conditional logic to report guesses that are too low
misconceptions.description: Rubric 0/1: The program does not contain any logic to determine when a guess is too low or to print a corresponding message.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student is not addressing the requirement to guide the user with "Too low" feedback.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should compare the user's guess to the secret number and print "Too low!" when the guess is less than the secret.
symptoms: No secret answer or guess variable in scope
No output strings indicating "Too low" or similar
misconceptions.root_cause: Focus on a numeric calculation task rather than the interactive game spec.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add an else-if branch such as else if (guess < answer) { System.out.println("Too low!"); } within the guessing loop.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The program lacks any game-like conditional messaging.

evidence.note: User prompts are for distance, mpg, and price, not guesses; no place to test for low guesses.

misconceptions.name: No game termination based on a correct guess
misconceptions.description: Rubric 0/1: There is no notion of a correct guess or termination condition tied to guessing correctly; the program simply ends after printing the driving cost.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the program should terminate after computing and printing a single result, not after a correct guess.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The guessing game must continue until the user guesses the secret number, and then terminate with a message indicating the number of guesses.
symptoms: No variable counting guesses
No condition that checks guess == answer
Program exits after a single calculation and print statement
misconceptions.root_cause: Implemented a single-pass calculation instead of a game loop with a specific winning condition.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an int guessCount and a loop that increments it each guess; end the loop and print a success message when guess == answer.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no tracking of guesses or equality check against a secret value.

evidence.note: Program simply computes and prints cost, then closes; no termination condition related to a correct guess.

misconceptions.name: Solved Incorrect Problem
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program for calculating road trip costs, entirely failing to implement the required Number Guessing Game as described in Q2. None of the game logic (random generation, guessing loop, conditional hints) is present.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely submitted an assignment intended for a different question or task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code must address the specified requirements of the Number Guessing Game.
symptoms: Code class name does not match the problem context (RoadTripCost instead of NumberGuessingGame)
The entire implemented logic is irrelevant to the required game.
Program output relates to cost/distance, not guessing.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misidentification or misplacement of the required assignment file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please submit the correct file containing the implementation for the Number Guessing Game.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code addresses a 'Road Trip Cost' calculation, which is objectively not the requested 'Number Guessing Game'.

evidence.note: The class name shows the code's intent is road trip cost calculation, not a number guessing game.
The main method implements road trip cost calculation logic (distance, MPG, price per gallon), confirming the wrong problem was solved.

misconceptions.name: Completely Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a road trip cost calculator instead of implementing the number guessing game as required by the problem statement.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either misread the assignment or submitted code from a different problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires implementing a number guessing game where the computer picks a random number 1-100, the user guesses repeatedly, and receives 'Too high' or 'Too low' feedback until they guess correctly.
symptoms: Code calculates driving cost instead of playing a guessing game
No use of Random class to generate a secret number
No loop for multiple guesses
No comparison logic between guess and answer
Program asks for distance, MPG, and price per gallon instead of number guesses
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for the wrong problem (likely a road trip cost problem from a different assignment or exercise).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start over with the correct problem. Implement: (1) Random number generation using the provided hint, (2) a do-while or while loop for repeated guesses, (3) an if-else chain to compare the guess to the answer and provide feedback, (4) a counter for number of guesses, and (5) output when the correct number is guessed.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: This is certain - the submitted code is entirely unrelated to the assigned problem. The class name 'RoadTripCost' and all functionality (readDouble, calculateCost) are for a different problem.

evidence.note: The entire program is calculating road trip costs, not implementing a number guessing game. The prompts ask for distance, MPG, and price - completely unrelated to the guessing game problem.
This function calculates road trip costs. The problem requires logic to compare guesses with a random number and provide 'Too high'/'Too low' feedback.
Only Scanner is imported. The problem requires Random class (Random rand = new Random(); int answer = rand.nextInt(100) + 1;) as specified in the hint.

misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem instead of the required number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to calculate the cost of a road trip instead of implementing the required number guessing game that uses a random number between 1 and 100 and interactive guessing.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should solve a road trip cost calculation problem here (read distance, MPG, and price per gallon, then compute cost).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: This question requires a number guessing game where the computer randomly picks an integer from 1 to 100 and the user repeatedly guesses until correct, with 'Too high'/'Too low' hints after each wrong guess.
symptoms: Program name and behavior are about road trip cost, not a guessing game
No use of Random or random number generation
No loop to allow multiple guesses
No conditional logic producing 'Too high' or 'Too low' hints
No termination condition based on a correct guess
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between questions or reusing code from a different assignment without adapting it to the specified number guessing game requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and rewrite the program to (1) generate a random int between 1 and 100, (2) repeatedly prompt the user for guesses using a loop, (3) compare each guess to the secret number and print 'Too high' or 'Too low' as appropriate, and (4) stop only when the user guesses correctly and report how many guesses were taken.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program solves a different problem (road trip cost) and contains none of the required elements for a number guessing game, indicating a clear mismatch with the specification.

evidence.note: Code implements a road trip cost calculator and does not contain any random number generation, guessing loop, or high/low feedback required by the number guessing game specification.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misunderstanding of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program for calculating road trip costs ('RoadTripCost') instead of the assigned task which was to create a 'Number Guessing Game'. The submitted code bears no conceptual resemblance to the required solution.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the provided code fulfills the requirements for a Number Guessing Game, or they mistakenly uploaded code from a completely different assignment (Road Trip Cost calculation).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required implementing a Number Guessing Game involving loops, conditional feedback, and random number generation (1-100).
symptoms: Code implements 'Road Trip Cost' calculation logic.
No evidence of random number generation (Random class).
No evidence of guessing loop (while/do-while).
No evidence of 'Too high'/'Too low' logic.
misconceptions.root_cause: Submission error or fundamental confusion about which task was being addressed.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment instructions carefully and submit the correct code for the Number Guessing Game.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The class name, variables (distance, mpg), and function names (calculateCost) clearly demonstrate implementation of cost calculation, which is entirely unrelated to the guessing game problem statement.

evidence.note: Class name indicates road trip calculation, not a guessing game.
Main logic uses variables specific to cost calculation, not game logic.
